articles.headline: Suit Offers a Peek at the Practice of Inflating a Legal Bill
articles.snippet: Legal scholars say a legal fight over fees is likely to reinforce a perception that law firms inflate bills by performing superfluous tasks.
articles.abstract: Legal scholars say a legal fight over fees is likely to reinforce a perception that law firms inflate bills by performing superfluous tasks.

articles.headline: With or Without Bailout, Cypriots Lose Trust in Banks
articles.snippet: Account holders, business customers and many experts worry that Europe’s solution to the banking crisis in Cyprus is only a temporary bandage.
articles.abstract: Account holders, business customers and many experts worry that Europe’s solution to the banking crisis in Cyprus is only a temporary bandage.
articles.lead_paragraph: NICOSIA, Cyprus — With her wedding day three months away, Despina Charalambous is desperate to gain access to her savings, which have been frozen at the Bank of Cyprus for more than a week. She plans to take out all her money once the banks reopen, even though the new bailout plan for her country supposedly guarantees the safety of her deposits.
articles.byline: By Liz Alderman and Landon Thomas Jr

articles.headline: What You Didn’t Post, Facebook May Still Know
articles.snippet: Facebook is no longer relying solely on what its users reveal. Instead, it is tapping outside data sources to learn even more about them, and to sell more finely targeted ads.
articles.abstract: Facebook is no longer relying solely on what its users reveal. Instead, it is tapping outside data sources to learn even more about them, and to sell more finely targeted ads.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Debra Aho Williamson, an advertising industry analyst and devoted coffee drinker, was intrigued by a promotion that popped up on her Facebook page recently. Sign up for a Starbucks loyalty card, it said, and get $5 off.

articles.headline: Emotion, Wild Card of Finances
articles.snippet: In this special section, prepared with American Public Media’s “Marketplace Money” radio program, a series of stories illustrate where money and emotions collide.
articles.abstract: In this special section, prepared with American Public Media’s “Marketplace Money” radio program, a series of stories illustrate where money and emotions collide.
articles.lead_paragraph: Few topics are as emotionally charged as money.

articles.headline: Puerto Rico Creates Tax Shelters in Appeal to the Rich
articles.snippet: The island has created tax breaks for interest, dividends and capital gains in an effort to lure affluent American executives from the mainland.
articles.abstract: The island has created tax breaks for interest, dividends and capital gains in an effort to lure affluent American executives from the mainland.
articles.lead_paragraph: Known for its white-sand beaches and killer rums, Puerto Rico hopes to stake a new claim: tax haven for the wealthy.
articles.byline: By Lynnley Browning and Julie Creswell

articles.headline: Skepticism From Court in Drug Case
articles.snippet: Several Supreme Court justices questioned the legality of some payments made by brand-name drug companies to potential generic competitors.
articles.abstract: Several Supreme Court justices questioned the legality of some payments made by brand-name drug companies to potential generic competitors.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Several Supreme Court justices expressed skepticism on Monday about the legality of payments by brand-name drug companies to potential generic competitors in exchange for keeping their cheaper, rival drugs off the market.

articles.headline: Now in Defense of Gay Marriage, Bill Clinton
articles.snippet: Bill Clinton’s journey from signing the Defense of Marriage Act to repudiating it mirrors larger changes in society as same-sex marriage has evolved from a fringe idea.
articles.abstract: Bill Clinton’s journey from signing the Defense of Marriage Act to repudiating it mirrors larger changes in society as same-sex marriage has evolved from a fringe idea.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — He had just flown across the country after an exhausting campaign day in Oregon and South Dakota, landing at the White House after dark. But President Bill Clinton still had more business before bed. He picked up a pen and scrawled out his name, turning a bill into law.

articles.headline: He Has Millions and a New Job at Yahoo. Soon, He’ll Be 18.
articles.snippet: Nick D’Aloisio, a programming whiz who wasn’t even born when Yahoo was founded in 1994, sold his news-reading app, Summly, to Yahoo.
articles.abstract: Nick D’Aloisio, a programming whiz who wasn’t even born when Yahoo was founded in 1994, sold his news-reading app, Summly, to Yahoo.
articles.lead_paragraph: One of Yahoo’s newest employees is a 17-year-old high school student in Britain. As of Monday, he is one of its richest, too.

articles.headline: Rise in  Sexual Assaults in Egypt Sets Off Clash Over Blame
articles.snippet: Women have begun turning to the news media to tell their stories as conservative lawmakers use their political platforms to criticize victims of rape.
articles.abstract: Women have begun turning to the news media to tell their stories as conservative lawmakers use their political platforms to criticize victims of rape.
articles.lead_paragraph: CAIRO — The sheer number of women sexually abused and gang raped in a single public square had become too big to ignore. Conservative Islamists in Egypt’s new political elite were outraged — at the women.
articles.byline: By Mayy El Sheikh and David D. Kirkpatrick

articles.headline: Obligations and Motivations in the Battle for Dell
articles.snippet: A three-way tug of war for control of Dell has developed, and it has put into focus the question — and perhaps the answer — of whether management-led buyouts are good or bad for shareholders.
articles.abstract: A three-way tug of war for control of Dell has developed, and it has put into focus the question — and perhaps the answer — of whether management-led buyouts are good or bad for shareholders.
articles.lead_paragraph: Leon Cooperman, the billionaire investor and longtime Wall Street denizen, was railing on Monday about the deal of the moment: Michael Dell’s $24 billion effort to buy out the troubled computer maker he founded.

articles.headline: Justices Say Time May Be Wrong for Gay Marriage Case
articles.snippet: Six justices questioned whether the case was properly before the court and hinted they might vote to dismiss it.
articles.abstract: Six justices questioned whether the case was properly before the court and hinted they might vote to dismiss it.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — As the Supreme Court on Tuesday weighed the momentous question of whether gay and lesbian couples have a constitutional right to marry, six justices questioned whether the case, arising from a California ban on same-sex marriages, was properly before the court and indicated that they might vote to dismiss it.

articles.headline: $616 Million Poorer, Hedge Fund Owner Still Buys Art
articles.snippet: A renowned art collector, Steven Cohen has bought Picasso’s “Le Rêve” from the casino owner Stephen A. Wynn for $155 million. It is at least the second $100 million-plus acquisition of art by Mr. Cohen in the last two years.
articles.abstract: A renowned art collector, Steven Cohen has bought Picasso’s “Le Rêve” from the casino owner Stephen A. Wynn for $155 million. It is at least the second $100 million-plus acquisition of art by Mr. Cohen in the last two years.
articles.lead_paragraph: Less than two weeks after SAC Capital Advisors, the hedge fund owned by the billionaire trader Steven A. Cohen, agreed to pay the government $616 million to settle accusations of insider trading, Mr. Cohen has decided to buy a little something for himself.
articles.byline: By Carol Vogel and Peter Lattman
